issues.text: whether where an application for withdrawal under s. 494 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is made on the ground of insufficiency or meagreness of reliable evidence that is available, it is an improper exercise of discretion for the Court to grant consent before evidence is taken, if it was reasonably satisfied, otherwise, that the evidence, if actually taken, is not likely to result in conviction.

anchor.surface_text: The legal question that arises from the above is whether where an application for withdrawal under s. 494 of the Code of Criminal Procedure is made on the ground of insufficiency or meagreness of reliable evidence that is available, it is an improper exercise of discretion for the Court to grant consent before evidence is taken, if it was

issues.text: whether in a case triable by a Court of Session, an application by the Public Prosecutor for withdrawal with the consent of the Court does not lie in the committal stage.

anchor.surface_text: His contention is that in a case triable by a Court of Session, an application by the Public Prosecutor for withdrawal with the consent of the Court does not lie in the committal stage. He lays emphasis on the wording of s. 494 which says that in cases tried by jury, any Public,

issues.text: whether the consent under s.494 requires the court to make a prima facie judicial determination of a triable issue like under ss.209 and 253 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be taken to place on the Court the responsibility for a prima facie determination of a triable issue. For instance the discharge that results therefrom need not always conform to the standard of no prima facie case under ss. 209 1  and 253 1  or of

issues.text: whether the court's function in granting consent under s.494 is merely to satisfy itself that the Public Prosecutor's executive discretion has not been improperly exercised.

anchor.surface_text: The judicial function, therefore, implicit in the exercise of the judicial discretion for granting the consent would normally mean that the Court has to satisfy itself that the executive function of the Public Prosecutor has not been improperly exercised,

arguments.claim: Granting consent under s.494 before evidence taken on ground of insufficiency of evidence is improper exercise of discretion as no judicial consideration of evidence.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Chief Justice who dealt with it was of the opinion that the consent should not have been granted. Accordingly, he set it aside. The learned Chief Justice recognised that normally in a matter of this kind the High Court should not interfere. But he felt called upon to set aside the order on the ground that there was no judicial exercise of discretion in the present case.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.494 gives executive discretion to Public Prosecutor; court checks improper exercise, not prima facie determination; wide grounds permissible including evidence insufficiency without full trial.

arguments.court_reasoning: s.494 wide and general; applies to all stages before judgment; historical evolution confirms covers inquiry stage; no discrimination for sessions cases.

arguments.claim: s.494 vests general executive discretion in Public Prosecutor to withdraw subject to court consent, on many possible grounds including evidence insufficiency.

anchor.surface_text: The judicial function, therefore, implicit in the exercise of the judicial discretion for granting the consent would normally mean that the Court has to satisfy itself that the executive function of the Public Prosecutor has not been improperly exercised,

arguments.claim: Court's consent under s.494 is judicial discretion but not requiring prima facie determination of triable issue like under ss.209/253; differs from full inquiry/trial.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be taken to place on the Court the responsibility for a prima facie determination of a triable issue. For instance the discharge that results therefrom need not always conform to the standard of no prima facie case under ss. 209 1  and 253 1

arguments.claim: s.494 applies at committal/inquiry stage in sessions cases; 'tried' not limited to post-inquiry; historical changes confirm wide scope.

anchor.surface_text: It appears to us that the analogy of the English practice would be misleading as an aid to the construction of s. 494. The scheme of our Criminal Procedure Code is substantially different.

arguments.claim: Private complainants have no locus standi to participate in withdrawal proceedings under s.494.

anchor.surface_text: There was some question raised before us as to whether the private complainants could be allowed to participate in these proceedings at the various stages. Nothing that we have said is intended to indicate that the private complainant has a locus standi.

arguments.claim: Court under s.494 must scrutinize grounds but can rely on pre-trial material; not surrender to PP but check abuse.

anchor.surface_text: the Court has to satisfy itself that the executive function of the Public Prosecutor has not been improperly exercised, or that it is not an attempt to interfere with the normal course of justice for illegitimate reasons or purposes.

arguments.claim: High Court cases sometimes fail to appreciate PP's executive role vs court's limited consent role under s.494.

anchor.surface_text: A large number of cases from the various High Courts have been cited before us. We have carefully gone through them. All of them recognise that the function of the Magistrate in giving consent is a judicial one open to correction.

arguments.court_reasoning: But insufficient appreciation of respective positions.

holdings.text: Where an application for withdrawal under s.494 CrPC is made on the ground of insufficiency or meagreness of reliable evidence, it is not an improper exercise of discretion for the Court to grant consent before evidence is taken, if it is reasonably satisfied that the evidence, if taken, is not likely to result in conviction.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, unable, with great respect, to subscribe to the view taken by the learned Chief Justice whose judgment is under appeal, that where the application is on the ground of inadequacy of evidence requiring judicial consideration, it would be manifestly improper for the Court to -consent to withdrawal before recording the evidence and taking it into consideration.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.494 vests wide executive discretion in PP; court checks for impropriety based on available material, not full judicial trial; engrafting requirement of evidence recording would narrow section impermissibly.

holdings.text: s.494 CrPC applies at the committal/inquiry stage in cases triable by Court of Session; no limitation excluding preliminary inquiry.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to construe s. 494 as involving any such limitation. The wording is perfectly wide and general and would apply to all classes of cases which are capable of terminating either in a discharge or in an acquittal, according to the stage at which the section is invoked.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Text wide and general; historical evolution from 1872/1882/1923 Codes confirms coverage of all pre-judgment stages including inquiry; no reason for discrimination between jury/non-jury sessions cases; 'tried' not limited to post-inquiry trial.

holdings.text: Consent under s.494 does not require the Court to make a prima facie judicial determination of a triable issue, unlike standards under ss.209/253 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be taken to place on the Court the responsibility for a prima facie determination of a triable issue. For instance the discharge that results therefrom need not always conform to the standard of no prima facie case under ss. 209 1  and 253 1  or of

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.494 aligns with executive initiative and court's supervisory role in pre-trial matters (ss.61/167 etc.); not inquiry/trial provisions; discharge/acquittal results differ from groundlessness standards.

holdings.text: In granting consent under s.494, the Court exercises judicial discretion to satisfy itself that the Public Prosecutor's executive discretion has not been improperly exercised or for illegitimate purposes.

anchor.surface_text: The judicial function, therefore, implicit in the exercise of the judicial discretion for granting the consent would normally mean that the Court has to satisfy itself that the executive function of the Public Prosecutor has not been improperly exercised,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows Privy Council in Bawa Faqir Singh; PP has general executive discretion on wide grounds; court prevents abuse without full adjudication; PP as officer of court provides fair view.

holdings.text: Consent under s.494 is not to be lightly given; Court must carefully scrutinize grounds of application, considering available pre-trial material.

anchor.surface_text: This is not to say that a consent is to be lightly given on the application of the Public, Prosecutor, without a careful and proper scrutiny of the grounds on which the application for consent is made.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Judicial function requires scrutiny to prevent improper interference; High Court cases affirm but some underappreciate roles; available evidence (FIR, police statements) relevant.

holdings.text: Private complainants have no locus standi to participate in proceedings under s.494 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Nothing that we have said is intended to indicate that the private complainant has a locus standi.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Obiter; proceedings concern PP's executive function and court's consent; private parties pursued but no indication of right.

edges.explanation: Holding directly answers the issue by affirming that withdrawal under s.494 on grounds of insufficiency or meagreness of evidence is not improper exercise of discretion.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, unable, with great respect, to subscribe to the view taken by the learned Chief Justice whose judgment is under appeal, that where the application is on the ground of inadequacy of evidence requiring judicial consideration, it would be manifestly improper for the Court to -consent to withdrawal before recording the evidence and taking it into consideration.

We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion, for all the above reasons, that the order of the High Court should be set aside and the appeals allowed. Accordingly, the order of the trial court is hereby restored.

edges.explanation: Holding directly answers the issue by confirming s.494 applies at committal stage in Sessions cases without limitation.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to construe s. 494 as involving any such limitation. The wording is perfectly wide and general and would apply to all classes of cases which are capable of terminating either in a discharge or in an acquittal, according to the stage at which the section is invoked.

We are, therefore, clearly of the opinion, for all the above reasons, that the order of the High Court should be set aside and the appeals allowed. Accordingly, the order of the trial court is hereby restored.
